Barclays has a trial running using a technology similar to Apple’s Passbook which uses a QR code as the access token. Once scanned the customer is sent directly to the login portal avoiding the password screen altogether, although the customer’s account details are still presented and the account pin is still required.

Barclays hopes to have Passport ready by the Christmas period for its customers with more complicated accounts such as mortgages and insurance.

“There are a few different ways of looking at it and depending on the service we’re providing,” said Nick Jones, head of digital at Barclays. “We were pretty clear we wanted a service to be simpler. We are using new technologies in different ways to make life simpler and we are moving into more areas where customers were getting confused.”

Jones says the new technology will mean fewer passwords

The bill aims to revoke parts of the UK government's 2016 Trade Union Act. It would mean current restrictions on industrial action in the NHS, the police, local authorities and further education would be lifted.

The government claims that the bill will bring the benefits of the Employment Relations Act to a variety of public and private sector workers.

It claims that the legislation would protect employees and business from the costs of strikes and lock-outs.

It argues that the government would not be giving legal recognition to trade unions, but giving them rights equivalent to those that are already given to trade unions. But the government maintains that there are currently more than 200,000 union members working on behalf of the unions - and that the legislation will not undermine the status of trade unions as recognised representatives of the staff of the NHS, local councils and the police.

Mmusi Maimane, 34, was clear favourite to succeed outgoing leader Helen Zille. Mr Maimane became party spokesman in 2011, was elected to parliament in 2014, and took the reins of the party in December.

The elections, due on 8 May, come two years after the ANC was narrowly beaten by the DA in the parliamentary elections, though it managed to hold onto government.

image copyright Getty Images image caption Cyril Ramaphosa has a firm grasp of the ANC's complex organisational structure

What does Mr Ramaphosa's appointment indicate about the direction in which the party is heading?

It makes him the most prominent and experienced South African to lead the ANC since Nelson Mandela retired in 1999. Mr Ramaphosa would now become the third party leader after Mandela and Thabo Mbeki, though he has been absent in recent years from the top positions.

He is highly regarded within the party for his political skill

Denis Donaldson was murdered in County Donegal in April 2006, months after being exposed as an agent who worked for the police and MI5 against fellow IRA inmates. He had served six years in jail before being granted compassionate release to Ireland, where he had three children. His ex-partner in crime, Séamus Donaldson, from Lurgan, County Armagh, received a life sentence for his part in the attack.

The Donaldsons were convicted of hiring the M60 gunman and ordering the prison attack. The Donaldsons were among a number of members of the Provisional IRA who were allowed into prison for the day, and given an opportunity to escape. When Denis Donaldson was found dead on the streets of County Donegal, the authorities believed that he had been murdered by the Real IRA.

The Real IRA was set up in September 2012 by a former member of the Ulster Volunteer Force

Cytherissa lacustris, a species of creature called ostracods, only grow to about a millimetre in length. Until now, there was only a fossil of the species, unearthed in 2005 in China, which left scientists debating about some of the animal’s most basic characteristics.“Its antennae do not have rings (like those of today's bristleworms),” Dr Olenin explained. “Moreover, the mandible of its mouth has never been observed clearly.”The discovery that Cytherissa is not a bristleworm but a new species has important scientific implications as the animal could show that the ancestor of modern bristleworms was not like the modern species. Raslan Fadl was Egypt's first doctor to be convicted of performing FGM, even though the still widespread practice was officially banned in 2008. In 2011, he was jailed for 14 years, following the successful prosecution of 27 others. He was released early.

Nine other doctors had also been convicted of FGM, but in 2010 an appeals court overturned their convictions on the grounds that what they had been accused of doing was not FGM at all, but a criminal offence called "licentious excision".

FGM is a practice that is thought to have originated in ancient Libya, and was prevalent across the Sahara, in parts of sub-Saharan Africa, and in areas of the Middle East. In the 15th and 16th centuries, it was also widely accepted in Britain and the European continent.

The first country where it was banned was Egypt in 2008, when a law against it was passed. FGM has been outlawed in a number

The house builder said the recent experiences of a significant number of customers "fell below the high standards they rightly expected". To tackle the problem Bovis would take legal action against the company that had supplied the material and would require all builders involved to take a new two-week training course called Building Better.

"Over the last 10 months, a significant number of customers have told us they have experienced poor treatment from Bovis," said the house builder. "Most commonly, this has involved an apparent failure to provide customer service, which included inadequate communication and response to complaints."

Bovis said the first course had been delivered to two training centres. A spokesman declined to comment directly on Fawley's departure but said it would "continue to work hard to ensure its customers are fully informed and satisfied".

The University of Calgary transferred 20,000 Canadian dollars-worth of bitcoins ($15,780; Â£10,840) after it was unable to verify the source of the funds.

The bitcoin is believed to have previously been held by the Canadian student who died during last year's flooding in Calgary.

The skeleton belongs to a small, plant-eating dinosaur which lived 200 million years ago - at the beginning of the Jurassic Period. Although it was part of a family of dinosaurs that roamed all over Europe at the time, the creature has an African story of its own.

Image copyright M. Norell Image caption "Juravenator", the name given to the creature by scientists

It is a species called Juravenator starki, named after the American palaeontologist Mary Katherine Norell, of the University of Chicago.

The dinosaur was "very common", Dr Norell told BBC News.

It was a predator, feeding mainly on small plant-eating dinosaurs. Its fossil bones are found all over Europe and its vertebrae are often found alongside dinosaur footprints.
